TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed LinearGradientBrush extends System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush

Docs.summary: Paints an area with a linear gradient.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A LinearGradientBrush paints an area with a linear gradient. A linear gradient defines a gradient along a line. The line's end points are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> properties of the linear gradient. A LinearGradientBrush brush paints its <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops%2A> along this line.
The default linear gradient is diagonal. In the default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being painted, and its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being painted. The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path.
The following illustration shows a diagonal gradient. A line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point.
![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient
The next illustration shows the same linear gradient, but with highlighted gradient stops.
![Gradient stops in a linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-4gradientstops.png "Gradient stops in a linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient with highlighted gradient stops
It is possible to specify a gradient axis that does not completely fill area being painted. When this occurs, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.SpreadMethod%2A> property determines how the remaining area is painted.
## Freezable Features A LinearGradientBrush is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object and therefore can be frozen to improve performance. For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see [Freezable Objects Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

Docs.summary: Creates a modifiable clone of this , making deep copies of this object's values. When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.
Docs.returns: A modifiable clone of the current object. The cloned object's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen%2A> property will be even if the source's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen%2A> property was

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

public System.Windows.Point EndPoint { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.Windows.Point EndPoint

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.
Docs.value: The ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient. The default is (1,1).

remarks.format: ## Remarks A paints a gradient along a line. The line's start and end points are defined by the and EndPoint properties of the . The default linear gradient is diagonal. In the default, the of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being filled, and its EndPoint is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being filled. The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path. The following image shows a diagonal gradient. The black line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point. ![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient ## Specifying Relative or Absolute Values Note that the property of a determines whether its EndPoint is interpreted as a relative or absolute value. A of specifies that the EndPoint value is relative to the size of the painted area. A of specifies that the EndPoint value is expressed in device independent pixels. By default, the is set to , making the EndPoint a relative value. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the starting two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A paints a gradient along a line. The line's start and end points are defined by the StartPoint and properties of the . The default linear gradient is diagonal. In the default, the StartPoint of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being filled, and its is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being filled. The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path. The following image shows a diagonal gradient. The black line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point. ![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient ## Specifying Relative or Absolute Values Note that the property of a determines whether its StartPoint is interpreted as a relative or absolute value. A of specifies that the value is relative to the size of the painted area. A of specifies that the StartPoint value is expressed in device independent pixels. By default, the is set to , making the StartPoint a relative value. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
